Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo F with PMHx NIDDM, HTN, CKD, chronic C diff s/p FMT on 
___, Afib on eliquis presenting with nausea, vomiting and 
abdominal pain for 2 days prior to admission.  
 
Patient initially presented to ___ where she 
received 2L NS, IV Zofran and was transferred to ___ for GI 
evaluation given recent stool transplant.  
 
In the ED, initial VS were 98.6 80 182/60 16 97% RA  
Exam notable for ill, thin female with DM, irreg-irreg rhythm, 
CTAB, soft non rigid abdomen periumbilical tenderness and 
suprapubic area, warm and dry skin, no ankle edema  

Labs showed  
- WBC 9.2 H/H 11.___.1 Plt 183 MCV 104  
- ALT 9 AST 19 ALP 87 T 0.6 Alb 4.0 Lipase 17  
- Mg 1.5 K 3.0 HCO3 20 BUN/Cr 36/2.5 AG 18  
- lactate 1.3  

Imaging showed  
- CXR: no acute cardiopulm process  

Received  
___ 17:15 PO Ondansetron ODT 4 mg  
___ 17:24 IV Ondansetron 4 mg  
___ 17:46 IVF NS ( 1000 mL ordered)  
___ 17:46 IV Diazepam 5 mg  
___ 18:10 IV BOLUS Diltiazem 20 mg x2  
 
ED course was complicated by afib with RVR (HR in 120s) and pt 
was treatd with IV diltiazem  

GI was consulted who felt that current symptoms are not related 
to colonoscopy and FMT and recommend broad work up and Cdiff if 
symptom profile fits.  

Decision was made to admit to medicine for further management.  
 
On arrival to the floor, patient reports that starting on ___ 
(___), she developed worsening nausea. Had BM on ___ that 
was soft, not diarrhea. Then starting ___, developed 
profuse vomiting with inability to tolerate anything PO. Not 
been able to eat or drink but has been taking medications, 
although vomiting afterwards. Vomiting bilious in nature. No 
diarrhea. Last BM was on ___. Mild abdominal discomfort and 
nausea. No sick contacts or unusual foods. Started probiotics on 
___. She notes that this is generally how her previous episodes 
of C diff colitis presented- started with n/v followed by 
diarrhea. Associated sx include dry mouth.  

She notes that for the last six months (both before and after 
the fecal transplant) she has daily vomiting in the morning x1. 
Takes a Zofran and feels better. Reports improvement in 
diarrhea- prior to transplant, had diarrhea daily and had to use 
immodium every day. Since transplant she generally has soft 
daily bowel movements. SHe has only experienced diarrhea several 
times.  

No fevers, cough, congestion, runny nose, chest pain. Notes she 
was having palpitations in the ED when her heart rate was high. 
No CP or DOE at baseline. Sometimes gets pedal edema but uses 
Lasix. No recent ___ edema. No worsening of dyspnea. No focal n/t 
or weakness but does endorse fatigue.  

Of note, patient was admitted to cardiology service in ___ with nausea, vomiting and diarrhea. LHC during that 
admission revealed no critical coronary lesions. NSTEMI was 
thought to be type 2 in the setting of hypertensive emergency 
and active C difficile Colitis.  

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:  
See above  
All other 10-system review negative in detail.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ year-old woman with h/o NIDDM c/b 
gastroparesis, HTN, CKD, GERD, duodenal ulcer c/b bleed in ___, 
recurrent C diff infection s/p FMT on ___, and Afib (on 
eliquis) here for continued nausea and vomiting and an inability 
to tolerate PO, found to be C. diff positive. Once treated for 
C.diff with oral vancomycin and when her glucose was under 
better control her nausea and vomiting resolved. She was very 
deconditioned at discharge, but cleared by ___ to go home with 
___ and home ___.

#NAUSEA/VOMITING C/F GASTROPARESIS FLARE: 
Pt w/ h/o NIDDM c/b gastroparesis, reported a month of N/V i/s/o 
recent fecal transplant for recurrent C. diff infection, p/w 
worsened vomiting and poor PO intake, now with frequent watery 
BMs noted after a few days inpatient (were soft but formed 
before that). Pt reports vomiting immediately after PO intake. 
Exam w/
diffuse mild tenderness and slightly increased distension from 
prior, but otherwise benign. DDx was initially most likely viral 
gastroenteritis (though noro negative) triggering a 
gastroparesis flare. However, when loose stools started, c.diff 
was checked, and positive, thought to be the cause. Poor blood 
glucose control may also be an exacerbating factors, as FSBG 
frequently >200. Once C.diff treatment was started and patient 
had tight glycemic control, her nausea and vomiting resolved. 

#PROTEIN CALORIE MALNUTRITION: 
Pt cachectic appearing, with minimal PO intake >1 week. N/V 
poorly controlled, unable to tolerate POs. Previously seen 
electrolyte abnormalities (low Mg, Phos, K) c/w malnutrition, 
but risk of re-feeding syndrome was felt to be low. No feeding 
tube requirement. Nutrition recommended 100 mg thiamine x5 days 
which was done. 

#RECURRENT C DIFF INFECTION: 
Pt w/ multiple loose BMs per day, C diff positive, so decided to 
treat despite possibility of a false positive with the FMT so 
recent (4 weeks prior). FMT was considered a failure and patient 
will need to discuss with her outpatient GI providers. She was 
treated with vancomycin Oral Liquid ___ mg PO/NG Q6H. 

#A-FIB WITH RVR: 
On tele in Afib/Aflutter. HR's improved with IVF boluses. RVR 
likely related to hypovolemia given N/V and inability to 
tolerate PO, dry appearing. Poor absorption of PO medications 
may also be a factor. Patient stabilized on diltiazem 45 mg Q6H. 
Volume status very tenuous, even diuresis with 20 mg IV Lasix + 
her usual 20 mg PO Lasix one day sent her into RVR. Continued 
home Apixaban 2.5 mg PO/NG BID 

#HFpEF: 
Echo in ___ with "Preserved biventricular systolic function. 
Mild mitral regurgitation. Borderline pulmonary artery systolic 
hypertension." Re-started home Lasix for SOB ___. As above, 
volume status was very tenuous, even diuresis with 20 mg IV 
Lasix + her usual 20 mg PO Lasix one day sent her into RVR. She 
was satt'ing well on RA and breathing comfortably at the time of 
discharge.

#GERD & H/O DUODENAL ULCER: 
Pt d/c omeprazole this past Novemeber. Per GI who saw her in 
clinic should switch to H2 blocker given increased risk of C. 
diff recurrence w/ PPI. Pt continues to c/o heartburn. Started 
ranitidine 150 mg PO daily.

#HYPERTENSION: 
Pt w/ h/o HTN. BPs were acceptable range for inpatient BP 
control (mild to moderate HTN). Continued home Carvedilol 6.25 
mg PO/NG BID.

#INSOMNIA: 
Pt c/o insomnia, not helped w/ ramaleteon, says only Zolpidem 
has worked for her in the past. Continued home Zolpidem Tartrate 
5 mg PO QHS:PRN insomnia.

CHRONIC/STABLE ISSUES: 
===============================
#NIDDM: 
H/o T2DM c/b gastroparesis. Last A1c in OMR is 6.0. Per pt was 
on pioglitazone b/c other oral agents did not control her sugars 
well, pt was counseled on risks of pioglitazone given HFpEF. 
Lantus + HISS while inpatient. Held home Pioglitazone and 
restarted at discharge. Consider switching to a new oral med in 
the future given the patient's CHF. 

#CKD: 
Baseline Cr appeared to be 2.4. Most recent Cr of 2.6 on ___ 
in ___. Cr stable and below baseline (possibly ___ 
malnutrition, or level of 2.0 is true baseline) at this time.

#CHRONIC BACK PAIN: 
Takes dilaudid at home. After discussion with the patient, this 
medication was help out of concern that it could be contributing 
to her nausea and vomiting. She did not have pain while in the 
hospital.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: 
====================================
CODE STATUS: Full Code 
CONTACT: No healthcare proxy on file
___ ___: 427
_________________________
FYI: 
- Patient's volume status is VERY tenuous. Giving her more than 
PO Lasix 20 mg in one day, regardless of her being slightly 
volume overloaded, sent her into Afib RVR. 
- Increased dilt ER to 180 mg daily for rate control 
- Presentation concerning for failure of recent FMT. Discharged 
on PO vancomycin. 
_________________________

[ ] Please check renal function at next appointment, discharge 
Creatinine 2.6. She reports Cr 2.5 is baseline.

gastroparesis flares

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

WHY YOU WERE ADMITTED:
- You were having nausea and vomiting

WHAT WAS DONE AND FOUND: 
- You were given fluids to treat dehydration
- We tested your stool and found C.diff, meaning that your fecal 
transplant failed
- We started oral vancomycin again

WHAT YOU SHOULD DO NOW: 
- You should follow up with your doctor appointments listed 
below
- Take your lasix pill as you were taking it before you came 
into the hospital. 
- Keep taking your oral vancomycin and follow the plan that Dr. 
___
- ___ have your labs drawn on ___ at a location convenient 
for you. These results will be faxed to Dr. ___

___ was a pleasure taking care of you,

Your ___ Team

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
